explanation:
To determine whether OS_BinSemCreate uses any compiler language extensions you must examine every macro, typedef, constant and object that the function references (macros are the most likely place extensions appear).

- OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_APINAME: These are macros invoked at the top of the function. Macros frequently hide compiler extensions (statement-expressions, typeof, inline assembly, attributes, etc.), so their full definitions must be inspected.
- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew: The call may use special calling conventions or inline attributes in its prototype/definition; inspect to ensure no extensions affect the caller context.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: Likely a macro/enum passed to OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew; its definition could be a macro expression using extensions.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro indexes the object table. Its expansion may use casts, typeof, container_of, statement-expressions or other extensions; the macro body is required.
- OS_bin_sem_table: The table symbol that OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET accesses; its type and definition help determine if any nonstandard constructs are needed to use it.
- OS_OBJECT_INIT: This macro initializes the object record and stores the name. Its expansion must be checked for extensions.
- OS_BinSemCreate_Impl: The platform-specific implementation is called with a token pointer; its prototype/definition may use extensions (attributes, nonstandard parameter types) that affect how the call is performed.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew: Finalization routine called with token and sem_id; inspect prototype/definition for any nonstandard usages.
- OS_object_token_t: The token type used throughout; its typedef/structure definition is needed to see whether unusual language extensions (bitfields with implementation-defined behavior, nonstandard alignment attributes, GCC extensions) are used.
- OS_bin_sem_internal_record_t: The record type pointed to by binsem. Required to inspect the member names/types (e.g. obj_name) and see whether any extension-only constructs are present.
- osal_id_t, int32, uint32: The used integer/ID typedefs; need their definitions to ensure they are standard types and not defined via compiler-specific extensions.
- OS_SUCCESS: The constant compared against return_code; inspect its definition (enum vs macro) in case it uses any extension syntax.
- obj_name: This identifier is referenced inside OS_OBJECT_INIT (as member name). Confirming it exists as a standard struct member and that the macro does not rely on nonstandard behavior requires the record definition.

Inspecting these symbols (macro bodies, typedef/struct definitions and function prototypes/definitions) will allow the next analyzer to determine whether any of them (and thus OS_BinSemCreate) employ compiler language extensions forbidden by the MISRA rule.
